haggerty_brittain-bodies-beach.name: The Bodies on the Beach: The epic Irish myth of Fionn MacCumhaill [Ben Haggarty & Steph Brittain]
haggerty_brittain-bodies-beach.tour_name: The Bodies on the Beach: The epic Irish myth of Fionn MacCumhaill
haggerty_brittain-bodies-beach.tour_description:
A fatherless son,



 A daughter's lament,



 A pig stolen from its spit,



 Fires burning out at sea,



 And a dream.



  On the westernmost tip of Ireland, a beach of crystal white sand once ran crimson with the blood of a never- ending magical battle — the last battle fought by the epic hero, Fionn MacCumhaill. 



 Ben Haggarty and Steph Brittain share a work -in -progress, picking through and piecing together fragments of voices, medieval manuscript, and song that tell a story of love and loss.



 Raw, lyrical, and unforgettable. This is not just a wild myth retold. It's an exploration of what it means to live, to regret, to sacrifice, and to endure in a relentless world.



 What will survive the tide? 



 This performance is followed by an opportunity for post-show discussion and is part of a Research and Development project funded by the Arts Council of England.



 Two halves 60 mins. Age recommendation 16 +



  Content advice: This show contains references to threat, violence and mutilation, incest, death in childbirth, and suicide, all contextualised within a paradigm of mythic narrative, archetype and metaphor.

tour_dates.price: £12, £10 concessions, £15 support the artist (+£1 booking fee)

gaz-brookfield-almost-all-village-halls-.tour_description: Following the success of his tenth studio album, Waiting For Wisdom, Gaz Brookfield takes to the road once again, bringing his chart topping blend of folk rock to the more rural parts of the country.

Dreaming the Great Bear [Nick Hennessey]
specificEvents.description: Here in the Finnish far north the light is just a little too bright and the dark a little too blinding, the rivers flow fast and deep and it's all too easy to get lost in the forest. Internationally acclaimed storyteller and musician Nick Hennessey forges a world into being. With electric harp, vocal looping and acoustic wizardry, he conjures a cosmos of the imagination. Expect a remarkable, elemental epic and a world of sound as we enter the wild, playful, and surreal territories of the Finnish myth, the Kalevala.

specificEvents.name: Madness, Merry Making and Liberation [Sarah Dovey]
specificEvents.description:
Dionysus is a God of many facets. Some may know him as the God of wine and merrymaking and it's not hard to see why that has become one of his most popular aspects. But along with the feasting and indulgence he also brings divine madness. And further still he stands for liberation and rebellion against the social and gender based norms that are so often forced upon us. Tales of Dionysus are tales of joy and freedom, tales of blood and tales of the extremes of human nature.



 This evening, Sarah Dovey will explore the many aspects of Dionysus by telling stories of his life, his loves and his vengeance.

specificEvents.showname: Stories Under the Stars: Fireside Myth & Music for Grown Ups

specificEvents.description: The Goddess is coming.... Enter the pine forest. Meet: Creator; Mother; Lover; Virgin; Crone. Bring a burning question and get an answer from the goddess's oracle! Be prepared for X_rated stories! Adults only.

specificEvents.description: A position has just opened in our More-than-Human Resources Department! As the heroic head of the hiring committee for the divine pantheon, it's up to you to put together a team of sacred scribes, astral accountants and celestial problem-solvers. Tim has got the candidates for you to consider. With the right team of Godly governors in place, this incorporeal corporation is going places.

specificEvents.description: Come and join the Dragon Storytellers in the Story Circle. Listen to their stories about Barmouth and Wales: some traditional, some written especially for the Welsh Whisperers Storytelling project. All are warmly invited to share a story of their own if they wish, in the Welsh language, bilingually or in English.

specificEvents.name: Warm Hearted Christmas Stories [Cath Edwards & Matt Vaughan]
Winter Tales [Tony "Monty" Hirst]
Tom Thumb [Amelia Ace Armande]
specificEvents.description:
It's the time of King Arthur, and young Tom wants more than anything to be a knight at the court of Camelot. There's just one problem: Tom is only the size of a thumb, and he has a bad habit of being eaten. Eaten by wolves and horses and cows and giants and...



 A madcap journey through many stomachs and many adventures, this is a 17th century fairytale for telling around tavern tables and at twelfth night feasts. Amelia Ace Armande brings to life one of Britain's most overlooked folklore heroes on his quest for recognition and glory.



 A tale of heart, soul, and plenty of guts!

specificEvents.name: Dark tales for dark nights — Christmas special [P. D. Brown]
specificEvents.showname: Dark tales for dark nights — Christmas special

specificEvents.name: A Dance with the Minotaur's Sister [Steph Brittain]
specificEvents.showname: A Dance with the Minotaur's Sister
specificEvents.description: Join storyteller Steph Brittain as she follows Ariadne's journey as it unravels through the maze of love, betrayal, loss, joy and the bulls and the bees. Before the thread and before the tangled and twisted maze, there was Ariadne full of life and rhythm. From a dance floor in the forest and the labyrinth's twisting and tangled passages to the starry skies of the Island of Naxos, Steph Brittain weaves an intricate tapestry of love, strength and courage.

specificEvents.name: Once Upon an Oddity: Deliciously Strange Tales for Winter Nights [ Mark Fraser]
specificEvents.showname: Once Upon an Oddity: Deliciously Strange Tales for Winter Nights
specificEvents.description: Mark Fraser is an itinerant storyteller, traversing the land with his original tales and weird stories. Join him for a selection of the odd, ghastly and vaguely unsettling tales from his own brain and around the world. A dark hour of devilish deeds and strange characters, just perfect for a dark winter's evening. A writer, an artist and the master of the bizarre story, Mark brings twenty years of storytelling experience to Wonder Monger at Cambridge Junction.

specificEvents.name: Dog Almighty! A Trickster show for Grown-Ups [Emily Hennessey]
specificEvents.showname: Dog Almighty! A Trickster show for Grown-Up
specificEvents.description:
Wild, irreverent, stupid, wise, dangerous and outrageously rude, Coyote has questions.



 BIG Questions.



 Looking for answers he crosses land and sky, breaks the rules, dances with illusion, cheats death and wreaks havoc at every turn. 



 Emily Hennessey stumbles through the chaos of parenthood and life while celebrating the great First Nation trickster, the original creator and fool, riffing on the blues and high on himself.



 Raw, rough and close to the edge.



 A storytelling show for adults.

specificEvents.name: Beowulf: Storytelling for Grown-Ups [Hugh Lupton]
specificEvents.description:
Beowulf is the oldest story in the English language - and it still has the power to raise the hairs on the back of the neck!



 It tells of a hero's life, a life that is mapped by three tremendous blood- curdling encounters.



 As a young man Beowulf defeats the monster Grendel and his even more terrifying Mother, the original creatures from the Black Lagoon. Then, as an old man, he tries his strength against a gold guarding Fire - Drake(a dragon).



 Alongside these adrenalin - charged encounters the story explores the journey we all make from the seeming invincibility of youth to the heroic vulnerability of old age. The story has had a tremendous effect on the imagination of many writers and poets, most notably J.R.R. Tolkien. Without Beowulf there would have been no Lord of the Rings.



 'Impossibly engaging storytelling' The Guardian



 Aimed at adults.

specificEvents.name: At Winters Heart (Solstice Storytelling) [Henry Everett & Hannah Sneyd]
specificEvents.description: Dartmoor-based storytellers Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd promise a rich evening of tales crafted especially for the Solstice. Blending traditional stories from around the world with original tales inspired by the land and the deepening shadows of the season, we will gather together to bring light, joy, and depth to this midwinter moment.

specificEvents.name: Haunting Tales and Festive Cheer [Royal Tales story club, Sutton Coldfield]
The Dead of Winter [Merl Fluin & Holly Medland]
specificEvents.description:
__Chilling tales for the Festive Season.__



 Step in from the cold and enjoy the fine tradition of ghost stories for the festive season. Storytellers Merl Fluin and Holly Medland will take you on a journey to the places where wraiths walk at night.



 The cafe will be open from 6: 30pm, serving hot food, drinks and delicious cakes to help keep the chill at bay. Storytelling starts at 7:15pm.

specificEvents.name: Mad Sprits and Wild Gods [Henry Everett]
specificEvents.description:
Prepare to be led astray into the medieval tales of Kent's beloved trickster, mischievous Faerie, Robin Goodfellow.



 Next we will travel to the furthest reaches of Ancient Greece to quake in the stories of the Great God Pan… Both beings are untethered and unruly, wild spirits of the land.

specificEvents.name: Kukolka [Ronnie Conboy]
specificEvents.description: Kukolka is a weaving of traditional Slavic wondertales with 20th century wartime narrative. At the heart of it all, the wisdom of Baba Yaga questions what choices are made, when all good choices are gone.

specificEvents.name: At Winters Heart (Solstice Storytelling) [Henry Everett & Hannah Sneyd]
specificEvents.description: Dartmoor-based storytellers Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd promise a rich evening of tales crafted especially for the Solstice. Blending traditional stories from around the world with original tales inspired by the land and the deepening shadows of the season, we will gather together to bring light, joy, and depth to this midwinter moment.

specificEvents.name: The Snow Queen [Vanessa Woolf]
Arnside Sailing Club — Storyteller [Nick Hennessey]
specificEvents.description: On the Sunday before Christmas, an afternoon show with Nick Hennessey, an internationally acclaimed storyteller, playwright, folk singer, song writer, harpist and musician.  He has performed at venues such as the South Bank, Barbican, Royal Albert Hall and festivals worldwide, He has broadcast on Radio 4 and his music played on Radio 3. Nick has a particular interest in the story telling tradition of Finland. He will take you to the snow filled forests of the Far North, the darkness of the winter night and the warmth of the winter fire, travelling by song, story and music.

specificEvents.name: Comb [Sarah Mooney]
specificEvents.description:
I saw a banshee once, just outside of Galway...



When Charlotte was 8 her Grandad told her the beginning of a story but refused to tell the full tale. Years later a chance encounter led her to find the rest of his story buried deep within an archive gathered from families in Ireland. Not only did she discover this unbelievable link to her past but also the more startling realisation that she might actually be cursed.



At times chilling, hilarious and moving Comb is a lament for the stories and people we have lost. Through a tangled ride into Celtic, Slavic and Siberian folklore, it is a clarion call for understanding just how interwoven we all are.

specificEvents.name: Storytelling Around The Fire - Warm Tales for Winter [Vanessa Woolf]
specificEvents.showname: Storytelling Around The Fire - Warm Tales for Winter
specificEvents.description: Gather by the warmth of the fire in our truly beautiful location. Relax and enjoy glorious, mystical, magical tales from storyteller Vanessa to light up the winter dark. Hot chocolate and marshmallows will be available. We will be sitting around the fire- but it is outside... so dress in your cosiest layers! [Limited tickets]

specificEvents.name: Tales and Ales — Tombs and Roses by Word of Mouth [P. D. Brown] [P. D. Brown]
specificEvents.showname: Tales and Ales — Tombs and Roses by Word of Mouth

specificEvents.name: Welsh Whisperers [Gillian Brownson + Dragon Storytellers]
specificEvents.description: Come and listen to stories about kings and queens, the Tylwyth Teg and fairies, dragons and monsters and ordinary people as well. Stories of Barmouth, Gwynedd and Wales, stories from long ago and tomorrow. The Dragon Storytellers will be joined by professional storyteller Gillian Brownson.

specificEvents.name: The Girl Who Married a Dog [Nell Phoenix]
specificEvents.showname: The Girl Who Married a Dog

specificEvents.name: Tall Tales and Tiny Truths ['Tis Tales]
specificEvents.description: Tall Tales and Tiny Truths - stories of wit, wisdom and wonder, with maybe just a tiny touch of truth woven in. Myths and mischief, legends and lies, these stories are made to be spoken and shared in good company. Brought to you by Holly Medland, Sue Bailey and Tony 'Monty' Hirst.

specificEvents.name: Dark tales for dark nights [Amy Douglas and Jason Buck]
specificEvents.description:
Ghost and horror stories for grown ups. Strange things lurk in the shadows — these are tales of held breath, hearts thumping and the relief of shutting the door on the dark.



 Join Amy Douglas and Jason Buck in a storytelling celebration for National Storytelling Week, and hear tales of dark myths from the wilds of the British countryside, to the eerie legends of what hides beneath the streets of old London town!



 Enjoy a drink included with your ticket, and make a night of it by adding our £25 dinner option, available before the show, from 5pm.



 Ages: Adults and teens (12+)

specificEvents.name: Myth, Magic and Mischief (age 5+) [Amy Douglas and Jason Buck]
specificEvents.price: £7.50 each or £25 family ticket (2 adults and 2 children)
specificEvents.description:
It's National Storytelling Week! If you're in the London area, it's a great opportunity to hear SGK regular storytellers, Amy Douglas and Jason Buck, in a storytelling celebration of the Isle of Britain.



 This land is layered in legend, full of stories of magic and mystery, boggarts and bogles, dragons and worms. Every mountain, field and river has a story to tell.



 45 minute storytelling sessions for children and families (age 5+).  Traditional myths, legends and folk tales of England, Scotland and Wales.



 Amy Douglas is a word-hoarder, a word-storer, a word-catcher and a word explorer. After winning 'Young Storyteller of the Year' at 16, Amy apprenticed to world-renowned traditional Scots Traveller and storyteller Duncan Williamson, and now holds many of his stories in trust. She's been a storyteller, performer and author for over three decades, with her three folk tales collections winning Storytelling World Awards.



 Jason Buck has been a performer most of his life including comedy and sword-swallowing — but his passion lies in telling stories. Jason makes an astonishing array of amazing vocal sound effects — but beware, many of stories end with 'pockets of poo!'

specificEvents.name: Myth, Magic and Mischief (age 5+) [Amy Douglas and Jason Buck]
specificEvents.time: 11.30am or half past noon (40 min. show)
specificEvents.price: £7.50 each or £25 family ticket (2 adults and 2 children)

It's National Storytelling Week! If you're in the London area, it's a great opportunity to hear SGK regular storytellers, Amy Douglas and Jason Buck, in a storytelling celebration of the Isle of Britain.



 This land is layered in legend, full of stories of magic and mystery, boggarts and bogles, dragons and worms. Every mountain, field and river has a story to tell.



 45 minute storytelling sessions for children and families (age 5+).  Traditional myths, legends and folk tales of England, Scotland and Wales.



 Amy Douglas is a word-hoarder, a word-storer, a word-catcher and a word explorer. specificEvents.name: The Fire, The Flame, and the Light [Maria Buckley Whatton]
specificEvents.showname: The Fire, The Flame, and the Light
specificEvents.description:
A baby born with a blue flame of hair



 A cursed horse and doomed lovers.



 A glorious Saint who presides over an Irish chip shop.



 Join us on Wed 21st Jan and let Maria Whatton stir the seeds of Spring with her stories! There will be a flaming goddess, a startling saint, Mary of Kildare, and many more besides.

specificEvents.name: Backstories [Chris Richardson]
specificEvents.description: Newspapers and court records tell the facts of the notorious of Suffolk and East Anglia, but what of the people behind them? Join the storyteller, Chris Richardson, as he explores the events of Behind Bars and brings to life the drama, characters and world of these events. Chris tells folk tales and historical stories in events and festivals across East Anglia. Suitable for an Audience 12+

specificEvents.name: Peronik: The Diary In The Attic [Marion Leeper]
specificEvents.showname: Peronik: The Diary In The Attic
specificEvents.description: Across myth and memory, two young men set out on separate quests: one for treasure, one for love. But both must beware the ogres waiting in the dark.

specificEvents.name: The Girl Who Married a Dog [Nell Phoenix]
specificEvents.showname: The Girl Who Married a Dog

specificEvents.name: Last Orders - A Storytelling Show [Mike Payton]
specificEvents.description: Three strangers gather in the corner of an inn, leaving the darkness of the road. As the windows rattle and the optics glow, their memories grow hazy but they cling to the stories that have nourished them on their journeys. But why are they there? And who is calling for them from the upstairs bar, ever more insistently? Inspired by The Canterbury Tales, the Cohen Brothers and quite a few lost nights in the pub, Mike Payton reflects on the stories that make us and keep us tethered to the world. One more for the road…

specificEvents.name: Tales By The Teign [Shane Ibbs]
Tales from Pixieland [Henry Everett]
specificEvents.description:
Deep in the South West, the sound of laughter choruses through the woods, along the mossy rocky river ways... Take care! Pixie tricks are close at hand! 



 You're invited to 'Tales from Pixieland' a storytelling show exploring the traditional tales of the Pixies, by performance storyteller Henry Everett.



 Pixies are recognised around the world as a mischievous member of the fairy race, but their traditional stories are traced back to the hills and valleys of Cornwall, Devon and Somerset. Let their tales re-enchant your connection to this land and to life.



 Henry has spent the past few years exploring the tales and folklore of the Pixie's and published 'Pixie Folk Tales' with the History Press, 2025.



 Aimed at adults, 12+

specificEvents.name: Work in Progress: Berserker [Marcus Pibworth]
specificEvents.description:
A Wild Norse Epic retold by Storyteller Marcus Pibworth



 A kingdom shivers beneath the shadow of a winged terror.



 Kings rise, kings fall and betrayal coils in every hall.



 Warriors hunger for the clash of steel. Whispers of old sorcery stir in the dark places of the world.



 Old wounds demand their due. Revenge begets revenge.



 Can Bodvar Bjarki—bear-strong, battle-scarred—rally the king's champions and lead them across the frozen breadth of the Northlands, outwitting gods and men, toward a destiny where only the bravest may stand against the gathering doom?



 Born of the same ancient narrative root that gave rise to the Old English epic Beowulf, but treading a path into strange and mysterious realms of its own, Marcus Pibworth's darkly comic retelling of an Old Norse saga leads you deep into the uncharted wilds of myth and legend.

specificEvents.name: Tales That Topple Tyrants: Live Storytelling for Grownups [Merl Fluin]
specificEvents.showname: Tales That Topple Tyrants: Live Storytelling for Grownups
specificEvents.description:
Once upon a time there was a very bad king. He stole from his subjects, laid waste to the land, told outrageous lies, declared war on his neighbours, and always got his own way...



Except he didn't.

specificEvents.name: Storytelling at the Kashmir Fringe [Tony 'Monty' Hirst]
specificEvents.showname: The Sin-eater of Ross & Other Tradtitional Tales
specificEvents.description: A stroytelling slot in a local music festival.

specificEvents.name: Tales Tattled & Told at StonyWords Literary Festival
specificEvents.showname: Tales Tattled & Told at StonyWords Literary Festival
specificEvents.description:
In 'Shapes' storyteller Gill blends a haunting Selkie tale set on the Isle of Harris with an Innuit folk tale, plus a story of the Albrecht Durer painting, 'The Hare.'



 Gill is a performance storyteller with a passion for encouraging the imagination to take her audiences to far away places and times! Patrick, a freelance musician and composer, weaves his harp tunes like golden magic around the words of the tales - shapeshifting selkies, hares and bears. 



 Some of Patrick's recent compositions include his settings of commissioned poems by Shropshire/Welsh poets, A Shropshire Lass, and his Cantata, The Gentle Earth of Wales, based on Welsh folksongs and poetry.



 We'll also have the fantastic music of Rebecca LaChance and the joyous stories of Lynette Hill, Pete Boyce and fingers crossed, the artistry of the newly cloaked Bard of Stony Stratford! Hosted by Stephen Hobbs.



 This event is intended for ages 16 and older.

specificEvents.name: An Evening of Sussex Folklore and Wine [Jon Mason]
specificEvents.showname: An Evening of Sussex Folklore and Wine
specificEvents.description:
Join us for an intimate, captivating night of traditional storytelling at Everflyht vineyard.



 Step back, or sideways, or deeper into a Sussex filled with story… This county is crammed full of fascinating folktales, from the Weald to the Downs, from the fields to the towns: smugglers' tunnels, fairies beneath the earth, witches becoming hares, ghostly black dogs. Wherever you go, there is a story to tell you the hopes, dreams and fears of people just like you. Come and join professional storyteller and local folklorist Jon for a night of tales, told live in person, to bring the magic and history of the place alive. You may never see the spaces we live in the same way again!



 The evening will feature two 40-minute sets with a relaxing interval, allowing time to chat and enjoy the vineyard atmosphere.



 Your ticket price includes the full storytelling performance and a glass of Everflyht wine.

specificEvents.name: The Glass Palace of the Moon-Maid [Shonaleigh]
specificEvents.showname: The Glass Palace of the Moon-Maid
specificEvents.description: The Glass Palace of the Moon-Maid is a magical wonder-tale spanning this world and the beyond, a tale of stars and comets and moons, life and death, love and betrayal,  two very magical cats, and the occasional goat. This tale belongs to the Cycle of Hillel, which is the first of twelve epic, latticed, interlinked cycles of stories passed down through generations of Drut'syla storytellers.

specificEvents.name: Crow Dog [TUUP]
specificEvents.description:
The lamposts leaned down to listen through the letterbox, Time tells the story of the past looking over the shoulder of the present while holding the hand of the future - listen if you have ears to hear' Tuup 



 'Tuup is recognised as one of the most inspiring storytellers from the African-Caribbean community - as well as the wider international community. Tuup embodies the African oral tradition of the griot' Keith Waithe

specificEvents.name: The Stealing of the Sun and Moon [Nick Hennessey]
specificEvents.showname: The Stealing of the Sun and Moon
specificEvents.description: Join Nick for a performance that journeys into the deep, snow-filled forests of the Finnish far north, where the river of the underworld flows dark and fast, and the summer sun shines just a little too bright. In this world created from shards of eggshell, the sun and moon are fought over, magic is done and undone, and life is shot through with bizarre ordeals, misguided passions, magical battles and transformations. Expect a remarkable performance of elemental epic.

specificEvents.name: The Homing Stone [Hugh Lupton]
specificEvents.description:
Arthur Ransome is well known as the author of the 'Swallows and Amazons' books. What is less well known is that as a young man he went to Russia to collect folk-tales and was swept into the maelstrom of the Russian Revolution. During the six years he lived in Moscow he became the only British journalist trusted by the Bolsheviks. He played chess with Lenin and fell in love with Trotsky's secretary Evgenia Shelepina. In England he was regarded with profound suspicion as a possible Soviet agent.



 In 1919 when Moscow was surrounded by counter- revolutionaries, he and Evgenia escaped. They travelled through Estonia with a horse and cart knowing they would be shot if recognised.



 In the Homing Stone master storyteller Hugh Lupton (who is also Ransome's great - nephew) tells the epic tale of that perilous and extraordinary journey.'s great-nephew) tells the epic tale of that perilous and extraordinary journey.

specificEvents.name: Letters Through Time - a traditional storytelling for adults. [Maria Credali]
specificEvents.showname: Letters Through Time - a traditional storytelling for adults.
specificEvents.description: This show was first created as part of an ACE funded commission for Festival at the Edge.

specificEvents.name: Crazy Kings & Killer Queens [Merl Fluin & Holly Medland]
specificEvents.description:
Performance storytellers Merl Fluin and Holly Medland present two popular Ventnor Fringe shows in one unmissable night:



 TALES THAT TOPPLE TYRANTS Once upon a time there was a very bad king. He lied, bullied, stole, cheated, and always got his own way… until he didn't. Merl Fluin tells weird and wonderful fairy tales about dastardly despots and how to defy them. 



 WHAT DO WOMEN WANT? When a hapless knight insults the Queen, she gives him a year to find the answer to a seemingly impossible question. If he fails, he'll lose his head. Cue magic, madness and medieval mayhem as he sets out on his quest. Holly Medland's hit show sold out fast at Ventnor Fringe.



 Storytelling starts 7pm. Total runtime 90 mins plus interval. Home-cooked meals available in the bar downstairs before the show. Stories suitable for age 16+.

specificEvents.name: Queen of Between [Lucy Lill & Sarah-Liisa Wilkinson]
specificEvents.description:
What happens...



When the goddess of childbirth crosses her legs?



When you're bound above chaos with golden threads?



When the weight of your grief means you can't walk on?



When you're neither living or dead so you don't fit in?



When you're… stuck?



That's when you need Hecate: Queen of Between, many-shaped and multi-tasking goddess of birth, death, witches, weasels, hellhounds, crossroads, thresholds and ghosts.



Barking at her heels, Lucy Lill and Sarah Liisa Wilkinson take up their torches, jangle their keys and bring you stories of letting go, squeezing through and moving on.



For ages 16+



75 mins, short interval, informal Q&A (optional!)

specificEvents.name: Touching the Light [Sharon Jacksties]
specificEvents.description:
The days are getting longer, and as we celebrate the returning light, here is a new show to share world-wide inspirational stories of hope and resilience. Collected for her most recent book, 'A History of the World in 100 Tales', their world wide wisdom will uplift you as your storyteller unfolds this '... magical, captivating and atmospheric journey...'



This new work has been developed as a companion to her critically acclaimed piece, 'Talking to the Dark' which recently toured Romania. She is delighted that it reflects this year's World Storytelling Day's theme of 'light in the darkness'



 Sharon Jacksties is a professional performance storyteller and author, performing and teaching storytelling here and abroad, and is the author of several anthologies celebrating our world heritage of traditional literature

specificEvents.name: Queen of Between [Lucy Lill & Sarah-Liisa Wilkinson]
specificEvents.description:
What happens...



When the goddess of childbirth crosses her legs?



When you're bound above chaos with golden threads?

That's when you need Hecate: Queen of Between, many-shaped and multi-tasking goddess of birth, death, witches, weasels, hellhounds, crossroads, thresholds and ghosts.

75 mins, short interval, informal Q&A (optional!)

specificEvents.name: Deliver Us From Evil [Ropetackle Storytellers]
specificEvents.description:
Storyteller Aaron Oliver shares the forgotten story of the first recorded case of Tourette's Syndrome — a 15th Century priest who believed he was possessed by a demon. With two vicars for parents and his own Tourette's diagnosis, Aaron dives into the mind of a religious leader at war with his own body and asks: how do the stories we tell ourselves change us? 



 Ropetackle Storytellers regulars Amelia Ace Armande and Joshua Crisp will be sharing short stories of hauntings and possessions.

specificEvents.name: A Harvest of Tales [Storytelling Ambassadors]
City of Ladies - Dinas y Lêdis [Tamar Eluned Williams & Jordan Price Williams]
specificEvents.showname: City of Ladies - Dinas y Lêdis
specificEvents.description:
The wheel of fortune turns. It makes the rich richer and the poor poorer. God knows it doesn't pay storytellers enough...



 In a lost city, stories interweave: riotous tales of love, lust, and intrigue. A girl is raised as a boy, embarking on a quest of self-discovery. A king falls in love with a werewolf. A wild wizard prowls the woods, waiting to be captured. The wheel of fortune will bring them all together.



 City of Ladies/Dinas y Lêdis is an exciting new collaboration between award-winning storyteller Tamar Eluned Williams and musician Jordan Price Williams (VRï, Elfen, Pendevig). Fusing bilingual storytelling and music to uncover the queer romances of the French medieval court, the show traverses a rich and layered landscape, from Cornwall to Wales to Brittany.



 Age restrictions: 16+



 Content restrictions: the show contains references to violence, sexual violence, childbirth, torture, and homophobic attitudes, contextualised within a medieval framework.



 The development of this show is supported by the Arts Council of Wales, in partnership with Awen Cultural Trust, Theatr Soar, TRAC and Cardiff Storytelling Circle.

specificEvents.name: In the time of GIANTS [The Travelling Talesman]
specificEvents.description:
They are big and some of them are clever (not many though!). Europe used to be thick with them.



 From Greek Zeus to Scandinavian Thor and from Cornwall's Jack the Hammer to the northern Molly Whuppie, Gods and humans have waged a devastating series of single combats against large and grotesque beings with dubious manners. In many myths the giants come first, often preceding even the gods themselves, frequently waiting for the human explorers of new lands.



 Often a force of oppression, representing the tyranny of might, some have their beginnings in the power of nature, some in actual people who have been exaggerated over the years and some we can only guess at.

specificEvents.name: Storytelling Night with Laura Sampson and Stacey Blythe
specificEvents.description:
The Cardiff Storytelling Circle presents a night of two halves from two exceptional stortellers. Join us for darkness and light, for stories from near and afar...



 Laura Sampson will be sharing 'Yamanba (or, She'll be Coming Round the Mountain)'.



 A tree floats down a river from the mountain and becomes a sacred statue: compassion personified. At the river's source squats an old, old lady whose fury can eat you alive, or keep you as safe as if you yourself were the mountain.



 People call her a demon - but once she was a goddess. Maybe. Who is she really? And in a time when youth, beauty and granted wishes are all that matters, who even cares?



 For years, the figure of Yamanba has led Laura a merry dance round the mountain to the myths, legends and parables of East Asia - plus the outer reaches of her own unenlightened mind - chasing the echo of a being that can still, if she wants to, raise holy hell.



 Laura Sampson is a British-Trinidadian storyteller, author and Japanese noh practitioner based in London. She tells stories of big emotions, surreal situations, and misunderstood old ladies - from all over the world.



 In the first half, Stacey Blythe will be singing and storytelling bilingually in Welsh and English. Stacey and her harp and accordion are always inside the telling, weaving music and magic through each story. You're invited to listen and to sing together in these stories.

specificEvents.description: A majestic, intimate and hypnotic re-imagining of Greek myths and legends weaving ancient stories, cosmic projections and a spine-tingling electro-acoustic soundscape.

specificEvents.showname: Tales from the Time Between Times
specificEvents.description: Tales from the Time between Times starting at 7.30pm . You will hear about Ghosts the Tylweth Teg and of course Y Mari Lwyd as we explore the dark tales of the Swansea valley and beyond.

specificEvents.name: The Girl Who Married a Dog [Nell Phoenix]
specificEvents.showname: The Girl Who Married a Dog
specificEvents.description:
At the northerly point of north, it gets very, very cold. In this snow-blinding place the weirdest, wildest stories are told...



Nell Phoenix revels in the earthy humour and passions of Arctic stories, peopled with unconventional families, the desperate and lonely-hearted, and elderly relatives whose attempts to assist are misguided, to say the least.



This is a place where what happens next is probably not what you'd expect — and some images will stay with you forever...



Age Guidance 18+

specificEvents.name: Stars and their Consolations [Daniel Morden, Hugh Lupton & Sarah Lianne Lewis]
specificEvents.description: A majestic, intimate and hypnotic re-imagining of Greek myths and legends weaving ancient stories, cosmic projections and a spine-tingling electro-acoustic soundscape.

specificEvents.name: Stirring Stories: An Imbolc Storytelling at MIC [Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd]
specificEvents.showname: Stirring Stories: An Imbolc Storytelling at MIC
specificEvents.description:
The days are lengthening, and green shoots are nudging their way through the soil. As winter loosens its icy grip on the world, it is time to celebrate Imbolc, the Celtic festival of early spring, whose name means 'in the belly.'



 Join us for Stirring Stories, a series of uplifting tales to stoke the fire within and rouse us from our winter slumber. Forget the to-do list, gather together and and allow your imagination to unfurl into the realm of myth and magic.



 This special event with Dartmoor storytellers Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd promises a vivid array of stories formed through deep communion with the landscape. Blending traditional tales from around the world with original stories, games and song, we curate our events to closely match the energy of the season.



 Things to note: This is a family-friendly event, with a 20-minute interval and food and drink available from The Lounge Cafe - please see the MIC website for further details.

specificEvents.name: The Petal Demon [Shonaleigh]
specificEvents.description:
The Petal Demon follows the story of a woman who is pursued by a mage, and how she's helped by Lilith to create a maze of flowers, that traps the mage and becomes a sanctuary for her. This woman becomes known as the Petal Demon, and through her wanderings she leaves legends behind her.



 Tickets on the door.

specificEvents.name: Stories & Stars: Storytelling in the wild heart of Plymouth
specificEvents.showname: Stories & Stars: Storytelling in the wild heart of Plymouth
specificEvents.price: Adult tickets £7, Children £4 (Under 4s go free) Concessions available
specificEvents.description:
Come one, come all, for a treasure-trove of stories around an open fire, at the Snapdragons community space in Plymouth. Feast your ears on tales both old and new, told by local storyteller Hannah Sneyd.



 Featuring reluctant moles, dancing rivers and sharp-witted crones, Hannah's stories inhabit the space between mythic realms and mundane modern life. She peppers her tales with insights from the natural world, and always tells with a healthy dose of humour.n


 Stories are suitable for all ages. We have seating available, but you are invited to bring something cosy to sit on (blanket, rug) and to dress warmly. A hot drink (dairy free) will be available.n


 If it's very wet or cold, we will use the indoor space at Snapdragons.

specificEvents.name: The Steed o' Bells [Iris Pibworth & Colin Rowan]
specificEvents.description:
A life for a story - A story for a life.



 This father and daughter duo bring to life a tale of thievery, giants, ghosts; and many a close brush with death. How much is a story worth? A reworking of a tale found across the British Isles in the 1800's, Colin and Iris bring a contemporary edge to these traditional tales with their unique style.

specificEvents.name: The Mighty Goddess [Sally Pomme Clayton]
specificEvents.description: The Goddess is coming.... Enter the pine forest. Meet: Creator; Mother; Lover; Virgin; Crone. Bring a burning question and get an answer from the goddess's oracle! Be prepared for X_rated stories! Adults only.

specificEvents.name: Sacred Herbs of Britain [Ropetackle Storytellers]
specificEvents.description:
Olwen, the daughter of a giant, has hair yellower than the broom and cheeks pinker than the foxglove. Everywhere she walks, she leaves a trail of white clover, and she lives in the mythic Welsh landscape of the Mabinogion — Wales's oldest collection of written stories.



Bilingual storyteller Claire Mace blends herb lore with the folk tales of Wales as she walks us through Olwen's territory — a land where every tree and plant has their own story to tell, and their own place in myth and history.



 This traditional storytelling performance has been developed thanks to the 'Gwobr Esyllt' Prize from Chwedl, the network of women storytellers in Wales.

specificEvents.name: Welsh Whisperers [Ffion Phillips + Dragon Storytellers]
specificEvents.description:
ome and listen to stories about kings and queens, the Tylwyth Teg and fairies, dragons and monsters and ordinary people as well. Stories of Barmouth, Gwynedd and Wales, stories from long ago and tomorrow. The Dragon Storytellers will be joined by professional storyteller Ffion Phillips.



Ffion is a bilingual storyteller and folk musician with a passion for breathing new enchantment into old tales and reworking scraps of forgotten material into fresh stories. Her work often explores environmentalist themes and the natural world(s), with much of her repertoire rooted deeply in her native Eryri. As part of the 'Harebell Tellers' alongside Ailsa Dixon she has brought her collaborative shows 'Hear us and Hasten' and 5 star sell-out 'Aderyn/Bird' to the Edinburgh Fringe.

specificEvents.name: Tales of Travellers and Fools [Ian Douglas]
specificEvents.description: Boat dweller and storyteller Ian Douglas, has a storytelling career that spans 32 years, he was first inspired to begin his journey by the late great Scottish traveller, Duncan Williamson. Ian has held the prestigious title of Fool of Muncaster Castle and was apprenticed to the renowned storyteller Taffy Thomas MBE, during Taffy's three year stint as Storytelling  Laureate. Along the way Ian has collected many a tale and we are delighted that he is bringing a choice, curated collection of them to us in Matlock.  Join us as he regales us with stories of Travellers and Fools, it's sure to be an evening of jolly japes.

specificEvents.name: The Sin-eater of Ross & Other Tradtitional Tales [Tony 'Monty' Hirst]
specificEvents.showname: The Sin-eater of Ross & Other Tradtitional Tales
specificEvents.description:
An evening of traditional storytelling with storyteller Tony 'Monty' Hirst, featuring legends of Ross-on-Wye (who is, or was, the sin-eater of Ross? How did Old Maid's Walk get its name?), tales of the Forest, and a traditional tale or two from the time of once...


 Age: grown-ups. Because stories aren't just for children..,.

specificEvents.name: A Dance with the Minotaur's Sister [Steph Brittain]
specificEvents.showname: A Dance with the Minotaur's Sister
specificEvents.description: Join storyteller Steph Brittain as she follows Ariadne's journey as it unravels through the maze of love, betrayal, loss, joy and the bulls and the bees. Before the thread and before the tangled and twisted maze, there was Ariadne full of life and rhythm. From a dance floor in the forest and the labyrinth's twisting and tangled passages to the starry skies of the Island of Naxos, Steph Brittain weaves an intricate tapestry of love, strength and courage.

specificEvents.name: Uncanny [Nell Phoenix]
specificEvents.description: Nell Phoenix paces a path from dusty Mesopotamia, to Ancient Egypt, through London's Bloomsbury, along a dingy road in Guatemala at dawn, and back to her own kitchen table — gathering up disturbing, unsettling, baffling, bewildering, sinister, UNCANNY stories.

specificEvents.name: The Mighty Goddess [Sally Pomme Clayton]
specificEvents.description: The Goddess is coming.... Enter the pine forest. Meet: Creator; Mother; Lover; Virgin; Crone. Bring a burning question and get an answer from the goddess's oracle! Be prepared for X_rated stories! Adults only.

specificEvents.name: The Petal Demon [Shonaleigh]
specificEvents.description: The Petal Demon follows the story of a woman who is pursued by a mage, and how she's helped by Lilith to create a maze of flowers, that traps the mage and becomes a sanctuary for her. This woman becomes known as the Petal Demon, and through her wanderings she leaves legends behind her.

specificEvents.name: Under a Hill, a King Lays Sleeping [Bernadette Russell]
specificEvents.showname: Under a Hill, a King Lays Sleeping
specificEvents.description:
Come join local author and storyteller Bernadette Russell for a wild and magical evening of Hampshire myth and folklore - featuring the tales of the King asleep beneath a hill which is perhaps a slumbering dragon, the giant Ascapart and his battles with Bevis of Hampton, an enchanted stone circle and a ghostly horse, our local witches and their spells, incantations and potions, the Otherworld and the Bentworth Thorn, and the grampus that lives in a Yew Tree. With stories, songs, poetry and even a spell from a Hampshire Grimoire - this will be a night to remember - guaranteed fun and packed full of ancient wisdom too!



 Come and let yourself be re-enchanted by this beautiful region full of chalk downlands, heathland, forest and coastline, bustling with rich legends and fairytales. With stories, songs, and poetry this will be a night to remember- guaranteed fun and packed full of ancient wisdom too!

musicEvents.name: Gaz Brookfield and The Company of Thieves, (Waiting For Wisdom tour)
musicEvents.description:
Following the release of his tenth studio album, Waiting For Wisdom, Gaz Brookfield takes to the road once more. Folk / Punk festival favourite, Brookfield has been at this for a while now. Since winning Acoustic Magazine Singer/ Songwriter of the year way back in 2010 he has continued to tirelessly tour the length and breadth of the country, building a strong and loyal following where he goes. 



 His last album, Morning Walking Club, saw Gaz achieve his first top 40 record, and it even got number 1 in the UK Official Folk Charts. Not a bad result for this fiercely independent musician, with no record label, no manager, and no agent — just a guitar, a van, and a steadfastly belligerent refusal to give in.

sixpenny-handley-village-hall.full_address: Sixpenny Handley Village Hall, Salisbury, SP5 5NJ

daniel-morden.name: Daniel Morden
daniel-morden.bio: Daniel Morden has been a professional storyteller since 1989. He has travelled the world, collecting and telling traditional stories. He has a huge repertoire, from timeless Greek myths and thrilling adventures to awful jokes. He has given the Opening Address at Sydney Writers Festival, won awards for his books and was recently awarded The Hay Festival Medal.

the-travelling-talesman-cliff-eastabrook.name: The Travelling Talesman (Cliff Eastabrook)
the-travelling-talesman-cliff-eastabrook.bio:
Cliff Eastabrook, aka 'The Travelling Talesmand', is spoken word narrative performer of myths, legends, folktales and the occasional poem, a storyteller! His energetic and engaging performance is adapted on a per gig basis for a wide variety of adult and family audiences. He has over twenty years professional experience, is a member of Equity and can provide risk assessments on request.



 He has toured the country from Penzance to York, for feasts, festivals and fun since the early nineties with tales of Norse Gods, Celtic mysteries, clever girls and dragon Slayers, medieval mayhem, giants, goblins and halloween horrors. He originally specialised in Northern European tales but stories are now drawn from all over the world. He is constantly expanding his repertoire, reading myths from various cultures, chasing down unusual variations on folk tales and researching, learning or creating new adventures for special theme or site specific events.

nell-phoenix.name: Nell Phoenix
nell-phoenix.bio:
Nell has been performing professionally since graduating from Goldsmiths College. She has performed with theatre companies for 12 years touring all around the world - from the Blackpool Grand to the Sydney Opera House; all over the UK, Ireland, Eastern and Western Europe, Australia and in all sorts of spaces and places in-between.



She is Artistic Director of StoryNight at Torriano, Kentish Town's thriving performance storytelling clubs for adults. Nell is a passionate promoter of storytelling as a contemporary performance art.

nick-hennessey.name: Nick Hennessey
nick-hennessey.bio:
Nick Hennessey is an internationally acclaimed storyteller, playwright, folk singer, song writer and musician. He has told stories for more than 20 years, performing at venues such as the South Bank Centre and Royal Albert Hall. He is particularly drawn to North European cultural traditions and has been awarded high honours in Finland for his work on their National Epic, Kalevala.



 He is a sought after artistic collaborator, working with top of the field musicians and storytellers. He has broadcast documentaries for BBC Radio 4 and his musical work has featured on BBC Radio 3’s Late Junction. With a deep appreciation for the key role that stories play in how we learn about and express ourselves and the world, whether in businesses or schools, he works extensively in helping draw out our natural storytelling skills.

cath-little.name: Cath Little
cath-little.bio:
Cardiff Storyteller and Singer Cath Little has 'rough magic' in her voice, and in her words “the gift of the story comes through.” She has a strong belief in the power of stories to connect us to one another, to the land, and to the people who once lived here.



 She tells traditional stories from her Irish English heritage and her Welsh homeland. Cath enjoys re-imagining and retelling stories from The Mabinogion.



 Cath helps run the Cardiff Storytelling Circle and curates their seasonal concerts, Tales for the Turning Year. She tells and listens to stories at Oasis, a Cardiff Charity which offers a warm Welsh welcome to refugees and asylum seekers.

bronia-evers.name: Bronia Evers
bronia-evers.bio:
Bronia is a storyteller, designer, maker and puppeteer.



Her practice combines spoken word storytelling with hand crafted performing objects, sets and puppets. Her current work focusses on creating moving panoramas - a pre-cinematic form of moving image (also known as crankies), and embedding these in live and digital performances.

cath-little-bronia-evers.name: Cath Little | Bronia Evers
cath-little-bronia-evers.bio:
Cardiff Storyteller and Singer Cath Little has 'rough magic' in her voice, and in her words “the gift of the story comes through.” She has a strong belief in the power of stories to connect us to one another, to the land, and to the people who once lived here.



Bronia is a storyteller, designer, maker and puppeteer. Her practice combines spoken word storytelling with hand crafted performing objects, sets and puppets. Her current work focusses on creating moving panoramas - a pre-cinematic form of moving image (also known as crankies), and embedding these in live and digital performances.

nick-hennessey-emily-hennessey.name: Nick  Hennessey | Emily Hennessey
nick-hennessey-emily-hennessey.bio:
Husband and wife team, Nick and Emily Hennessey are both acclaimed storytellers in their own right.



Nick Hennessey is an internationally acclaimed storyteller, playwright, folk singer, song writer and musician. He has told stories for more than 20 years, performing at venues such as the South Bank Centre and Royal Albert Hall. He is particularly drawn to North European cultural traditions and has been awarded high honours in Finland for his work on their National Epic, Kalevala.



Emily Hennessey is a playful and dynamic performance storyteller with a great love of Hindu mythology. She has travelled over 10,000 miles across India and Nepal by train, bus, rattling rickshaw and bicycle. Emily has toured in India, Iceland and Japan and performed at venues and festivals across Europe. She spent many months at the Kattaikkuttu School in Tamil Nadu, learning from the children who perform stories from the Mahabharata through music, dance and song.

sarah-rundle.name: Sarah Rundle
sarah-rundle.bio: Sarah Rundle is a professional storyteller based in west London. She trained in community storytelling in South Cheshire, and in acting at Drama Studio London. Over the last nineeen years, Sarah has performed at a diverse range of venues, from museums and theatres, to pubs, cafés, and a Saxon longhouse.

sarah-mooney.name: Sarah Mooney
sarah-mooney.bio:
Stories that transform, ceremonies that reconnect, wisdom that remembers 



 For twenty-five years, Sarah has been walking a ceremonial path — unwinding old tales so their original wisdom can flow through again, creating spaces where stories become medicine.



 Sarah trained with Clarissa Pinkola Estés (author of Women Who Run With The Wolves) and actors from the legendary Peter Brook Company, learning that the deepest stories aren't just told — they are lived, embodied, remembered. For the last fifteen years, She has supported initiation rites and vision quests, working with and learning from shamans in Mexico and Ecuador, discovering how the old ways of storytelling can guide transformation.

dave-tonge.name: Dave Tonge
dave-tonge.bio: Professional storyteller, author & historian. He tells at museums, heritage sites, festivals, fairs and schools. Also known as The Yarnsmith of Norwich.

sharon-jacksties.name: Sharon Jacksties
sharon-jacksties.bio:
Sharon Jacksties tells stories to audiences of adults, young people and families.



 Her dynamic and versatile performances draw on stories from all over the world.



 Interpreting the wisdom of traditional material for contemporary audiences, her repertoire includes tales that have rarely been heard in this country.

sally-pomme-clayton.name: Sally Pomme Clayton
sally-pomme-clayton.bio:
'One of the country’s most highly regarded storytellers…she awakens the imagination of the audience.'  The Independent



'Virtuoso storyteller Sally Pomme Clayton has that rare gift of being able to transport the listener to other worlds, by completely inhabiting those worlds herself. Her stories are authentic and full of colour, she uses language like a painter. Her telling goes right through the skin and settles deep in the marrow of the listening bones — a wondrous experience.' Venue magazine, Bristol

monty-the-anywhens.name: Monty + The AnyWhens
monty-the-anywhens.bio: Isle of Wight based storyteller (Tony 'Monty' Hirst plus folk and blues duo, THe AnyWhens (Glenn Koppany and Sue Caiun) telling combinations of songs and stories, as well as thematic fringe festival shows.

tim-ralphs.name: Tim Ralphs
tim-ralphs.bio:
Tim Ralphs is a storyteller and active exponent of narrative in art. He also works as a public engagement consultant where he focuses on connecting academic researchers with non-specialists.



His storytelling is rooted in the oral tradition: The craft of a speaker weaving language and gesture to entrance an audience and bring a tale to life.



 His stories are drawn from a rich medley of myth and folk tale, but also include live adaptations of absurd texts and wondrous reimaginings of classic fairytale material in evocative urban settings. As an ambassador and advocate for storytelling, Tim’s repertoire reflects the need for the craft to appeal to today’s listeners and tomorrow’s tellers.

welsh-whisperers.name: Welsh Whisperers
welsh-whisperers.bio: Memeners of the Dragon Storytellers, performing in the Welsh language, bilingually or in English.

red-phoenix-the-prize-old-mummers.name: Red Phoenix | The Prize Old Mummers

katy-cawkwell.name: Katy Cawkwell
katy-cawkwell.bio:
Katy Cawkwell has been working as a professional storyteller since 1996 in venues across the UK and beyond.



 She creates contemporary, dramatic performances for adult audiences, based on traditional narratives.  Her shows have appeared in a wide range of venues: major theatres (inc. Barbican Pit Theatre, Soho Theatre, Derby Guildhall), storytelling clubs and nine international storytelling festivals (inc. a 2 week tour of India in 2016).  Katy was one of four storytellers shortlisted for the Arts Foundation Storytelling Fellowship and has featured on Radio 3 (The Verb) and Radio 4 (The Storytellers).

kersti-stabi.name: Kersti Stabi
kersti-stabi.bio: Storyteller and singer. Kersti was one of the storytellers who founded and built the Fabula storytelling company based in Stockholm. After ten rich and hugely enjoyable years on the board and on the Fabula stage she left the company, still working in collaboration with them as often as she can.

cath-edwards.name: Cath Edwards
cath-edwards.bio: Cath Edwrds is a storyteller, telling stories to adult audiences, family audiences, very young children, school-age children, and children and young people with special needs.

matt-vaughan.name: Matt Vaughan
matt-vaughan.bio: Matthew is a storyteller of 10 years experience. He has worked since 2011 in a Public Library Service in the East-Midlands and has been lucky enough to be able to develop his storytelling practice in his professional environment, performing stories and providing interactive workshops to audiences of all ages. He has worked in early years settings, primary and secondary schools and performed in clubs. He loves to perform international folk tales and wonder tales of all kinds as well as having particular interest in the stories of working folk of Britain, drawing on stories from his own coal mining heritage and beyond, and stories about nature the wild places of this world.

cath-edwards-matt-vaughan.name: Cath Edwards | Matt Vaughan
cath-edwards-matt-vaughan.bio:
Cath Edwrds is a storyteller, telling stories to adult audiences, family audiences, very young children, school-age children, and children and young people with special needs.



Matthew is a storyteller of 10 years experience. He has worked since 2011 in a Public Library Service in the East-Midlands and has been lucky enough to be able to develop his storytelling practice in his professional environment, performing stories and providing interactive workshops to audiences of all ages. He has worked in early years settings, primary and secondary schools and performed in clubs. He loves to perform international folk tales and wonder tales of all kinds as well as having particular interest in the stories of working folk of Britain, drawing on stories from his own coal mining heritage and beyond, and stories about nature the wild places of this world.

tony-monty-hirst.name: Tony "Monty" Hirst
tony-monty-hirst.bio: Isle of Wight based traditional stroyteller, Tony 'Monty' Hirst has been a listener of tales for over thirty years and a teller for five. Coming up through the ranks of folk nights and open mics, he regularly performs his own shows, as well as telling pop up tales in teas tents at music festivals around the country. A keen collaborator, he peforms with folk and blues duo The AnyWhens, and folk punk fiddle player Sophie Kate.

amelia-ace-armande.name: Amelia Ace Armande
amelia-ace-armande.bio: Ace began telling professionally with the Brighton Storytellers, and has told at the 'Get A Word in Edgeways' Spoken Word Festival, the Oxford Storytelling Festival, Beeston Tales and the Crick Crack Club. Ace toured Austria as a storyteller with Helbling Publishing. Ace is a founder of the Ropetackle Storytellers Club and mentor for the Step Up Spoken Word initiative.

steph-brittain.name: Steph Brittain
steph-brittain.bio: Steph Brittain's love for storytelling developed whilst studying Kathak dance in Paris and Delhi and it continued to grow during her MA in Drama and Movement therapy. She trained in performance at Acting International in Paris and Drama Centre London and has performed at Royal Exchange Theatre Manchester, Arcola Theatre London and for the BBC. A new voice storyteller, Steph Brittain joined Pandvani108 in 2022 as part of their artist development programme.

mark-fraser.name: Mark Fraser
mark-fraser.bio: Mark Fraser is an itinerant storyteller, traversing the land with his original tales and weird stories. Join him for a selection of the odd, ghastly and vaguely unsettling tales from his own brain and around the world. A dark hour of devilish deeds and strange characters, just perfect for a dark winter's evening. A writer, an artist and the master of the bizarre story, Mark brings twenty years of storytelling experience to Wonder Monger at Cambridge Junction.

emily-hennessey.name: Emily Hennessey
emily-hennessey.bio: Emily Hennessey is a playful and dynamic performance storyteller with a great love of Hindu mythology. She has travelled over 10,000 miles across India and Nepal by train, bus, rattling rickshaw and bicycle. Emily has toured in India, Iceland and Japan and performed at venues and festivals across Europe. She spent many months at the Kattaikkuttu School in Tamil Nadu, learning from the children who perform stories from the Mahabharata through music, dance and song.

hugh-lupton.name: Hugh Lupton
hugh-lupton.bio:
Hugh Lupton is an award-winning storyteller, performer and author. He is also a poet and lyricist. His work spans over 35 years, working on both solo projects and in partnership with other artists, writers, musicians, illustrators and performers.



He has toured both nationally and internationally and has performed at the RSC, the National Theatre and the Barbican, as well as at schools, community venues and arts centres the length and breadth of Britain. His repertoire ranges from Greek epic to Grimms Fairy Tales, from Norse and Celtic myth to East Anglian folk-tales, from the Great War to John Clare. Thematically his work often explores our place in the landscape and the deep cultural memories we carry.

henry-everett.name: Henry Everett
henry-everett.bio: Henry Everett is a storyteller, telling tales in the oral storytelling tradition, passed down through the generations. He tells traditional tales inspired by our connection to the land, of spirits of place and our human relationship with the magical landscape.

hannah-sneyd.name: Hannah Sneyd
hannah-sneyd.bio: Hannah Sneyd is a storyteller and healer based in the Dartmoor wilds. Her original stories arrive on the wind and thread a canny path between the familiar and the fantastical.

henry-everett-hannah-sneyd.name: Henry Everett | Hannah Sneyd
henry-everett-hannah-sneyd.bio: Henry Everett is a storyteller, telling tales in the oral storytelling tradition, passed down through the generations. He tells traditional tales inspired by our connection to the land, of spirits of place and our human relationship with the magical landscape.

royal-tales-story-club-sutton-coldfield.name: Royal Tales story club, Sutton Coldfield

merl-fluin-holly-medland.name: Merl Fluin | Holly Medland
merl-fluin-holly-medland.bio:
__Chilling tales for the Festive Season.__



 Step in from the cold and enjoy the fine tradition of ghost stories for the festive season. Storytellers Merl Fluin and Holly Medland will take you on a journey to the places where wraiths walk at night.



 The cafe will be open from 6: 30pm, serving hot food, drinks and delicious cakes to help keep the chill at bay. Storytelling starts at 7:15pm.

ronnie-conboy.name: Ronnie Conboy
ronnie-conboy.bio: Kukolka is a weaving of traditional Slavic wondertales with 20th century wartime narrative. At the heart of it all, the wisdom of Baba Yaga questions what choices are made, when all good choices are gone.

vanessa-woolf.name: Vanessa Woolf
vanessa-woolf.bio: Vanessa Woolf tells stories for adults and kids. Vanessa is a founder of Elephant Tales (ex Story Co Op) London's beautiful free Sunday open-mic storytelling club, and lead storyteller of Connection With Wonder, who provide storytellers, programme festivals and offer year-round training.

ben-haggarty-steph-brittain.name: Ben Haggarty & Steph Brittain
ben-haggarty-steph-brittain.bio:
Ben Haggarty is Artistic Director of the Crick Crack Club and one of the UK’s most popular contemporary performance storytellers. Renowned for his playful, physical and often challenging performances, his repertoire spans Indo-European fairytales for grown-ups, Greek and Irish mythology, the epic of Gilgamesh and contemporary myths of Frankenstein and The Sandman, which won him a Fringe First award for best spoken word.



Steph Brittain's love for storytelling developed whilst studying Kathak dance in Paris and Delhi and it continued to grow during her MA in Drama and Movement therapy. She trained in performance at Acting International in Paris and Drama Centre London and has performed at Royal Exchange Theatre Manchester, Arcola Theatre London and for the BBC. A new voice storyteller, Steph Brittain joined Pandvani108 in 2022 as part of their artist development programme

gillian-brownson.name: Gillian Brownson
gillian-brownson.bio: Gillian Brownson is as story artist, multi-disciplinary practitioner blending writing, storytelling, acting, singing & illustration.

gillian-brownson-dragon-storytellers.name: Gillian Brownson + Dragon Storytellers
gillian-brownson-dragon-storytellers.bio: Gillian Brownson is as story artist, multi-disciplinary practitioner blending writing, storytelling, acting, singing & illustration.

tis-tales.name: 'Tis Tales
tis-tales.bio: 'Tis Tales is a storytelling troupe (Holly Medland, Sue Bailey and Tony 'Monty' Hirst) telling tales to adult audience on the Isle of Wight.

amy-douglas.name: Amy Douglas
amy-douglas.bio:
Amy Douglas is a vibrant professional storyteller with a passion for traditional stories and riddles.



 Over the past twenty years she has delved deep into the folklore of Britain, reveling in tales of the strange and macabre; memories of magic and otherworlds; proud recollections of folk history; stories to make you smile, sigh or shiver; stories that have been moulded by the land, weather and generations of tongues wagging.

jason-buck.name: Jason Buck
jason-buck.bio: Award-winning performance storyteller, author and illustrator.

amy-douglas-and-jason-buck.name: Amy Douglas and Jason Buck
amy-douglas-and-jason-buck.bio:
Amy Douglas is a vibrant professional storyteller with a passion for traditional stories and riddles. Over the past twenty years she has delved deep into the folklore of Britain, reveling in tales of the strange and macabre; memories of magic and otherworlds; proud recollections of folk history; stories to make you smile, sigh or shiver; stories that have been moulded by the land, weather and generations of tongues wagging.



Jason Buck is an award-winning performance storyteller, author and illustrator.

ian-douglas.name: Ian Douglas
ian-douglas.bio:
Ian Douglas is a Storyteller and Theatre Maker Who works extensively across the British Isles. With over 20 years of experience delivering storytelling, performance and theatre activities for schools, arts organisations, communities and festivals across Britain, he has developed a practise approach which mixes sensitivity, Commedic energy and wit leading to a style all of his own.



 The origins of Ian's work are steeped in the traditions of street theatre which has helped him develop his unique storytelling style. His work has been described as 'truly inspirational' and draws upon a rich vein of British folk tales and world myths.

maria-buckley-whatton.name: Maria Buckley Whatton
maria-buckley-whatton.bio:
Maria Whatton is a treasured storyteller and fiction author. A winner of Outstanding Female Storyteller of Great Britain in 2013 (British Awards for Storytelling Excellence) she is renowned for her compelling, vibrant performances.



 She has a vast knowledge of traditional stories passed down by her Irish father and grandmother which she brings to life with her lucid, engaging style.

chris-richardson.name: Chris Richardson
chris-richardson.bio: Chris Richardson has been telling stories a long time — as long as he can remember. But it has only been the last 10 years or so that he have sought out audiences to share the wonder of how things are, should be or could be in our wildest dreams. He has been described as quirky, in part becuase ge can't resist fiddling with a story as it comes to him, or writing something new if it says what he wants to say. All the old stories were new once, and it's up to the storytellers of today to keep the old tales relevant and to add original ones that reflect and record the way we live today.

marion-leeper.name: Marion Leeper
marion-leeper.bio:
Marion Leeper is based in Cambridge, and is familiar visitors to museums, schools and libraries around the region. She has toured her shows for grownups to clubs and festivals around the country and internationally. She tells stories for children of all ages, and specialises in multi-sensory storytelling for the very young and for people with learning difficulties, working with the charity Bag Books.



 She is a long time member of the local group Cambridge Storytellers, and is currently involved in organising the East Anglian Storytelling Festival.

mike-payton.name: Mike Payton
mike-payton.bio:
Mike Payton has been telling tall tales all his life, and decided to turn this into a career in 2008. He was Lancastrian born, but is now based in Nottingham, drawing his tales from Britain's rich heritage and also from the four corners of the earth. His delivery is  warm and engaging, and he has a penchant for the strange and unexplainable.



 For the past 10 years, Mike has co-run the ever popular Beeston Tales with ace storyteller Tim Ralphs, a monthly storytelling club that brings the best of contemporary storytelling to an adult audience. As well as his work in schools, he has performed at museums, galleries, festivals, castles, pubs, clubs and cafes throughout the land. Early in his career he was the winner of The Black Country Story Slam, and was invited by The Society for Storytelling to perform at their annual gathering. He performed at The Wellcome Trust’s Day of the Dead celebrations on a day when the gallery had its busiest ever day: He has visited over 250 schools across the UK and Europe, performing and running workshops to all ages.

marcus-pibworth.name: Marcus Pibworth
marcus-pibworth.bio: Shane is a modern day Oral Storyteller who first heard traditional stories as a child from his father, then often repeated them to his siblings and eventually his own three children. In 1997 Shane went to Canada and while he was there, he was invitated to meet with the indidgenous Metis people and be part of  their Ceremonies and a Story Healing Circle, an immense privalage. This experience not only rekindled Shane's storytelling spark, it also provided a profound shift in his thinking as he began to use 'Applied Storytelling' as a Social Worker and then as a Counselling Therapist. His life long storytelling journey continued, with fresh insight.

lynette-hill-stephen-hobbs-rebecca-lacha.name: Lynette Hill, Stephen Hobbs, Rebecca LaChance, Peter Boyce, 2026 Bard of Stony Stratford, Gill and Patrick Larley

jon-mason.name: Jon Mason
jon-mason.bio:
Storyteller based in Brighton.



 Jon tells stories about times gone by and the modern day, blending fact and fantasy, from all over the world, for kids and grownups. Jon has given performances and workshops at festivals, community events, schools, spoken word nights, and storytelling clubs around the country — he creates shows and sessions to suit all needs.



 Jon is also a folklorist and cultural historian, researching stories in the context of their time, place and social meaning. He has appeared as a guest on BBC Radio, and teach up to university level on storytelling skills, folklore and more.

tuup.name: TUUP
tuup.bio:
TuuP was born in London of Guyanese parents.



 In the early 80s, Tuup was recognised by a small guyanese publishing house, run by Jessica & Eric Huntley, called Bogle L'Ouverture Press.



 Tuup joined the famous West London Storytelling Unit, run by artistic-director, Ben Haggarty and assistant-director, Georgiana Kebbel, a challenging innovative arts group looking at performance storytelling for adults.



In the mid 80s, Tuup formed a storytelling group with Flora Devi called 'Tellers of Time' (indian dance & folk tales coupled alongside african-caribbean tales & rhythms).

shonaleigh.name: Shonaleigh
shonaleigh.bio:
Word weaver, tradition bearer and educator



 Shonaleigh is a dedicated and committed storyteller actively working to expand and share the Drut’syla tradition. Brought up in the Drut’syla tradition by her Bubbe (grandmother) she has a repertoire of over three thousand stories which can be adapted as appropriate for the theme and audience with whom she is working.

maria-credali.name: Maria Credali
maria-credali.bio:
Storyteller and artist based in Lichfield, in the Midlands of England. Maria Credell creates unique and memorable storytelling shows for adults and work as a performer, educator and workshop facilitator. She is a registered Artsmark practitioner and a trained creative mentor, specialising in trauma informed practice.



 Working orally and unscripted, she reworks ancient stories for modern audiences. Maria works with theatres, heritage organisations, festivals, schools, private and community groups. She can help bring myths and legends to life at your school, to celebrate special occasions with friends, and to provide unforgettable experiences for listeners. Previous clients include The Royal Shakespeare Company, Festival at the Edge and many national and international festivals.

tamar-eluned-williams-jordan-price-willi.name: Tamar Eluned Williams & Jordan Price Williams

daniel-morden-hugh-lupton-sarah-lianne-l.name: Daniel Morden | Hugh Lupton | Sarah Lianne Lewis
daniel-morden-hugh-lupton-sarah-lianne-l.bio: A majestic, intimate and hypnotic re-imagining of Greek myths and legends weaving ancient stories, cosmic projections and a spine-tingling electro-acoustic soundscape.

owen-staton.name: Owen Staton
owen-staton.bio: Welsh Storyteller and Performer and host of The Time between Times Storytelling podcast. Ever since he was a small child, Owen has been fascinated by the amazing myths and legends that were born on his doorstep. Owen has performed all over the world as a Storyteller and Actor for over thirty years. He is available for storytelling bookings or podcast appearances and can design and write storytelling sessions for all ages. Owen also has experience as a stage, television, and Voice actor and is an experienced public speaker lecturer, and theatrical director.

henry-everett-and-hannah-sneyd.name: Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd
henry-everett-and-hannah-sneyd.bio:
The days are lengthening, and green shoots are nudging their way through the soil. As winter loosens its icy grip on the world, it is time to celebrate Imbolc, the Celtic festival of early spring, whose name means 'in the belly.'



 Join us for Stirring Stories, a series of uplifting tales to stoke the fire within and rouse us from our winter slumber. Forget the to-do list, gather together and and allow your imagination to unfurl into the realm of myth and magic.



 This special event with Dartmoor storytellers Henry Everett and Hannah Sneyd promises a vivid array of stories formed through deep communion with the landscape. Blending traditional tales from around the world with original stories, games and song, we curate our events to closely match the energy of the season.



 Things to note: This is a family-friendly event, with a 20-minute interval and food and drink available from The Lounge Cafe - please see the MIC website for further details.

iris-pibworth-colin-rowan.name: Iris Pibworth & Colin Rowan
iris-pibworth-colin-rowan.bio:
A life for a story - A story for a life.



 This father and daughter duo bring to life a tale of thievery, giants, ghosts; and many a close brush with death. How much is a story worth? A reworking of a tale found across the British Isles in the 1800's, Colin and Iris bring a contemporary edge to these traditional tales with their unique style.

ffion-phillips-dragon-storytellers.name: Ffion Phillips + Dragon Storytellers
ffion-phillips-dragon-storytellers.bio:
ome and listen to stories about kings and queens, the Tylwyth Teg and fairies, dragons and monsters and ordinary people as well. Stories of Barmouth, Gwynedd and Wales, stories from long ago and tomorrow. The Dragon Storytellers will be joined by professional storyteller Ffion Phillips.



Ffion is a bilingual storyteller and folk musician with a passion for breathing new enchantment into old tales and reworking scraps of forgotten material into fresh stories. Her work often explores environmentalist themes and the natural world(s), with much of her repertoire rooted deeply in her native Eryri. As part of the 'Harebell Tellers' alongside Ailsa Dixon she has brought her collaborative shows 'Hear us and Hasten' and 5 star sell-out 'Aderyn/Bird' to the Edinburgh Fringe.

bernadette-russell.name: Bernadette Russell
bernadette-russell.bio: Author, performance storyteller, theatre maker, workshop facilitator, cabaret MC , playwright and tree planter. Bernadette performs her own stories as well and traditional stories everywhere- including cabarets, sheltered housing, schools, parks, gardens, forests, vintage clothes shops, launderettes, beaches, in peoples beds, once even inside a Police Box! She loves being outside and can often be found in the woods. She write stories on walls, chalk poetry onto pavements and leave magical notes inside strangers pockets

gaz-brookfield-and-the-company-of-thieve.name: Gaz Brookfield and The Company of Thieves
gaz-brookfield-and-the-company-of-thieve.bio:
West country based Gaz Brookfield is an award winning solo acoustic musician, with two number one albums to his name.



 He has spent the last fifteen years tirelessly touring all over the UK and beyond, building a strong and loyal following wherever he goes.



 Brookfield was the first independent musician to sell out Bristol's The Fleece (450 cap) and The Bierkeller (750 cap) and more recently SWX (1000 cap). 



 Gaz has an impressive ten album strong back catalogue. In the autumn of 2023, Gaz's ninth album, 'Morning Walking Club', saw him achieve his first number one in the Official UK Folk Albums Chart.



 Brookfield got his second number one album in September 2025, when 'Waiting for Wisdom' topped the Official UK Download Charts.



 Not a bad result for this fiercely independent musician, with no record label, no manager, no agent - just a guitar, a van, and a steadfastly belligerent refusal to give in.

jess-silk.name: Jess Silk
jess-silk.bio: Jess Silk is a guitarist, singer and songwriter from the Black Country. Her passionate and  melodic brand of folk/punk music gets people sitting up and listening. Armed only with an increasingly sticker-covered acoustic guitar, lyrics right from the heart and a distinctive, powerful voice that many don't expect, Jess plays to audiences up and down the UK and has shared stages with many well known names among the folk/punk scene.

nick-parker.name: Nick Parker
nick-parker.bio:
Glastonbury based Nick Parker started gigging in his early teens playing mandolin and singing in folk/rock/skiffle band 'Why?', and spent the next 10 years bouncing around on stages at hundreds of venues and festivals around the UK and Europe. In 2010 Nick embarked on a solo career and has since enjoyed over 30 tours around the UK and Europe, releasing five full-length albums along the way, many songs from which have been featured on BBC6 Music among many other radio stations.



 Although primarily a solo effort Nick often plays with his band 'Nick Parker and the False Alarms' which is a folky/rocky/country affair using guitars, fiddle, pedal steel, banjo, mandolin, cornet, accordion, keys, whistles, pipes, bass and drums, often with various members switching instruments when space permits. At a recent gig the band were described as 'A British Arcade Fire', something that Nick was very pleased about. Nick also often gigs as a duo with fiddle player Ben Wain.

jess-silk-matt-johnson.name: Jess Silk + Matt Johnson
jess-silk-matt-johnson.bio:
Jess Silk is a guitarist, singer and songwriter from the Black Country. Her passionate and  melodic brand of folk/punk music gets people sitting up and listening. Armed only with an increasingly sticker-covered acoustic guitar, lyrics right from the heart and a distinctive, powerful voice that many don't expect, Jess plays to audiences up and down the UK and has shared stages with many well known names among the folk/punk scene.



Matt Johnson is a Midlands based Singer / songwriter who really wears his heart on his sleeve at the same times as completely captivating his audience. His subjects range from his family and the love of his life through to his view of the world now and his opinion on the plight of the oceans and our wildlife. He has a fantastic ear for melodyand bulids a hook into every song that has his audience singing back at him by the second chorus.

sorrel-nation.name: Sorrel Nation
sorrel-nation.bio: Travelling troubadour Sorrel Nation brings a soulful mix of folk-rock to country and beyond and possesses one of those voices that makes you immediately stop what you're doing to give her your full attention. She engages audiences with emotive lyrics, 70s inspired style and a voice full of soul, which further increases the seductive power of her songs. Known for penning songs that can truly open the heart to grief and like all valued songwriters possess a giving presence...she heralds gorgeous ballads that could become Sorrel Nation's trademark sound.
